be.kuleuven.distrinet.scalar.requests

Class Request

  • java.lang.Object
    • be.kuleuven.distrinet.scalar.requests.Request
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    DistributedGetTestRequest, DistributedPutTestRequest, RemoteSocketRequest, RemoteTestRequest, TestRequest, TimingTestRequest

    public abstract class Request
extends java.lang.Object

    A Request encapsulates the interaction between a User and the system under test. The abstract Request class itself does not implement any specific communication protocol, and is completely application agnostic. However, it provides all functionality required to automate the collection and processing of results by Scalar.

    For each specific way to interact with the system under test (e.g., logging in, accessing a resource, logging out), a concrete Request type should be created. All request statistics are automatically broken down per request type.

    For a Request object to be correctly processed by Scalar, the following should hold.

    First, requests explicitly need to be taken into account, i.e., it should be issued by an effective user u, so that for u User.isKeepingAccountOfRequest(Request) is true for this request. That is done by passing the effective User that created the request object, as well as 'true', to the constructor Request(User, boolean). Note that it is possible to explicitly lose track of request objects (for instance, helper requests that are only required for setup or tear down tasks, and are not part of the scalability analysis) by passing 'false' to Request(User, boolean).

    Second, request objects should be timed. Each request object has a millisecond-accurate timer which is controlled via the startTimer() and stopTimer() methods. A call to these methods should surround the minimal code necessary to interact with the system under test.

    Third, a request object needs to be assigned a result via the done(RequestResult) method. See RequestResult for available result options. Note that requests need to be marked as done(RequestResult) before they can be processed by the statistics engine.

    Author:
    Thomas Heyman

    • Constructor Detail

      • Request

        public Request(User usr,
               boolean keepAccountOfRequest)
        Construct a new request object created by the specified User usr. If keepAccountOfRequest is set, the new request object will be retained by usr (i.e., usr.isKeepingAccountOfRequest(this) holds). If, additionally, the new request object is created when usr is measuring (i.e., usr.isMeasuring() holds), then the new request object will be incorporated in the final statistics.
        Parameters:
        usr - The effective user object that created this request.
        keepAccountOfRequest - Whether the request should be kept into account by usr, or discarded after use.

      • Request

        public Request(User usr,
               boolean keepAccountOfRequest,
               java.lang.String shortName)
        Construct a new request object created by the specified User usr. If keepAccountOfRequest is set, the new request object will be retained by usr (i.e., usr.isKeepingAccountOfRequest(this) holds). If, additionally, the new request object is created when usr is measuring (i.e., usr.isMeasuring() holds), then the new request object will be incorporated in the final statistics.
        Parameters:
        usr - The effective user object that created this request.
        keepAccountOfRequest - Whether the request should be kept into account by usr, or discarded after use.
        shortName - The short name to use for this request (e.g., when describing results). If null, defaults to the short class name of this request type.

    • Method Detail

      • statisticallyRelevant

        public final boolean statisticallyRelevant()
        Check whether this request counts for calculating the final results for the scalability analysis of the system under test. This value is determined by user() at time of creation, and depends on whether user() was currently measuring, i.e., User.isMeasuring().
        Returns:
        Whether this request object was created during a measuring period.

      • id

        public java.lang.String id()
        Returns the ID of this request object. This method is used by the RequestReporter plugin when dump_each_request is true. It defaults to the object's hash code, but can be overridden to provide more meaningful identifiers if required.
        Returns:
        The textual representation of the ID of this request.

      • startTimer

        public final void startTimer()
        Start the internal timer to measure the residence time of this request.

      • stopTimer

        public final void stopTimer()
        Stop the internal timer to measure the residence time of this request.

      • isDone

        public final boolean isDone()
        Check whether this request is already marked as done. Note that this does not necessarily imply that this request has timing data associated with it, see hasTimingData().
        Returns:
        Whether a result has been set via done(RequestResult).

      • hasTimingData

        public final boolean hasTimingData()
        Check whether this request has timing data associated to it, i.e., that either timing data has been set via calling startTimer() and stopTimer(), or
        Returns:

      • setStartTime

        public final void setStartTime(long startTime)
        Sets the start time of this request to the specified value.
        Parameters:
        startTime - The start time, in nanoseconds.

      • setStopTime

        public final void setStopTime(long stopTime)
        Sets the stop time of this request to the specified value.
        Parameters:
        stopTime - The stop time, in nanoseconds.

      • done

        public final void done(RequestResult result)
                throws RequestException
        Mark this request as done. The request is assigned the specified result.
        Parameters:
        result - The result of this request.
        Throws:
        RequestException - When the result is different from RequestResult.NO_RESULT (i.e., the request was already assigned a result).

      • data

        public final RequestData data()
        Returns the basic data contained within this request (i.e., start time, stop time, and result), as a serializable RequestData object.
        Returns:
        The basic data of this request object.

      • getShortName

        public java.lang.String getShortName()
        Gets the short name, i.e., a label, for this request type. This value is used to distinguish between different request types for the calculation of final request statistics. By default, the simple name of the class is returned, but if a more fine grained breakdown of request results is required, this method should be overridden to return distinct names per request breakdown.
        Returns:
        The short name of this request object.
